Employee Handbook Section Generator for Nonprofits

BEFORE YOU START: Gather This Information (examples in parentheses)
Organization Basics:
- [ORGANIZATION NAME]: (e.g., River Valley Food Bank)
- [SECTION TOPIC]: (e.g., Remote Work; Paid Time Off; Workplace Safety)
- [MISSION/PROGRAM CONTEXT]: 1 sentence (e.g., We distribute food to 5,000 families monthly across three counties)

Legal & Compliance:
- [JURISDICTIONS]: (e.g., California; New York and New Jersey)
- [IMPLEMENTATION DATE]: (e.g., January 1, 2025)
- [REVIEW FREQUENCY]: (e.g., annually; every two years)

Staff Details:
- [STAFF TYPES]: (e.g., full-time, part-time, seasonal, interns)
- [WORK MODES]: (e.g., hybrid; fully remote; on-site only)
- [UNION STATUS]: (e.g., non-union; SEIU Local 123 members)

Your Capacity:
- [CAPACITY NOTES]: (e.g., Executive Director manages HR 3–5 hours/week; one part-time operations coordinator handles HR)
- [CONTACT ROLE]: (e.g., Operations Director; Executive Director)

Style Preferences:
- [READING LEVEL]: (e.g., 8th grade; high school; general adult)
- [TONE] (choose ONE; examples below)
  - FORMAL example: “Employees must submit requests using the Time Off Form within 48 hours of the absence. Supervisors approve or deny within two business days. Failure to follow these steps may result in the absence being unpaid.”
  - WARM example: “Please use the Time Off Form and let your supervisor know within two days of any absence. We try to respond within two business days. If you’re unsure what to do, ask—we’re here to help.”
  - CASUAL example: “Need time off? Fill out the Time Off Form and give your supervisor a heads-up within two days. We’ll aim to confirm in a couple of business days. Questions? Just ping your supervisor.”
- [LANGUAGE ACCESS]: (e.g., Spanish; Spanish and Mandarin; English only)

Approval Chain:
- [PREPARED BY]: (e.g., Operations Coordinator)
- [APPROVED BY]: (e.g., Executive Director and Board Personnel Committee)
- [LEGAL REVIEW]: (e.g., Pro Bono Partnership; Smith & Associates; internal review only)

Optional Settings:
- [WORD COUNT RANGE]: (default 500–750; use 800–1,100 for complex topics like harassment; 350–550 for simple topics like dress code)

YOUR PROMPT:
Draft an Employee Handbook Section for [ORGANIZATION NAME] on [SECTION TOPIC], aligned with our mission ([MISSION/PROGRAM CONTEXT]) and compliant with [JURISDICTIONS] law. This is for a small nonprofit team with [CAPACITY NOTES].

Formatting Rules:
- Use numbered section headers (1–13) with the exact titles below.
- Use short paragraphs and bullet lists where helpful.
- Procedures must be a numbered checklist with who/what/when and named forms/tools.

Required Structure (follow this exact order):
1. Title
2. Policy Statement – 2–4 sentences stating what is required/allowed/prohibited (not aspirational)
3. Purpose/Values Link – 1–2 sentences tying to our mission
4. Scope/Eligibility – Specify:
   - Staff types: [STAFF TYPES]
   - Union status: [UNION STATUS]
   - Work modes: [WORK MODES]
   - Volunteers/contractors: included or excluded
5. Definitions – 3–5 plain-language terms
6. Procedures – Numbered steps with WHO does WHAT by WHEN; include forms/tools; realistic for [CAPACITY NOTES]
7. Legal/Compliance References – Name relevant [JURISDICTIONS] laws/regulations; note when local law supersedes this policy
8. Exceptions & Accommodations – How to request disability/religious accommodations; Contact: [CONTACT ROLE]; response timeframe (e.g., within 5 business days)
9. Reporting/Confidentiality/Anti‑retaliation – Reporting channels; privacy limits; anti-retaliation; recordkeeping and retention timeframes (or “per local law”)
10. Roles & Responsibilities – Employee; Supervisor; Operations/HR; Executive Director; Board (if applicable)
11. Related Policies – Cross-reference 2–4 connected sections
12. Effective Date/Review – Include:
    - Effective: [IMPLEMENTATION DATE]
    - Review: [REVIEW FREQUENCY]
    - Version control template: “Version [X.X] | Effective [DATE] | Last Reviewed [DATE]”
    - Disclaimer: “This policy does not create an employment contract.”
13. Employee Acknowledgment – 30–60 words employees can sign

Content Requirements:
- Length: [WORD COUNT RANGE]
- Tone: [TONE] (use the style demonstrated in the examples above)
- Reading Level: [READING LEVEL]
- Include 1–2 brief nonprofit scenarios (e.g., outreach coordinator at a mobile pantry; program manager on a grant-funded event day)
- Stands Alone: The section must be understandable without reading other sections; cross-references are allowed but not required for basic comprehension.
- Language: plain, specific, enforceable; avoid legalese, vague timelines, and corporate jargon.
- Equity & Accessibility: note [LANGUAGE ACCESS]; include accommodations; ensure fairness across roles and work modes.

What to AVOID:
- Unenforceable promises (“we will always…”)
- Copying statutes verbatim
- Vague timelines (“soon,” “promptly”)
- Procedures requiring tools/staff we don’t have
- Conflicts with union collective bargaining agreements (if any)

Final Elements:
- Authorship Line: “Prepared by [PREPARED BY] | Approved by [APPROVED BY] | Legal review: [LEGAL REVIEW]”
- Equity Note: Flag any potential disparate impacts and how this policy mitigates them.
- Review-Ready: Draft must be suitable for board and legal review with minimal edits.

QUALITY CHECK (Review AI Output Against These):
- Too legalistic? → “Rewrite Procedures in simpler language at [READING LEVEL] with shorter sentences.”
- Too vague? → “Make the Policy Statement specific. Replace vague phrases with concrete timeframes or criteria.”
- Procedures too complex for small team? → “Simplify Procedures for [CAPACITY NOTES]. Reduce steps/forms.”
- Missing nonprofit context? → “Add one example for [specific role] during [specific program activity].”
- Tone off? → “Adjust the tone to be more [WARM/FORMAL/CASUAL] throughout, especially Procedures and Acknowledgment.”
- Contradicts existing policy or law? → “Reconcile with our [OTHER POLICY] and [JURISDICTIONS] law; revise for consistency.”
- Length off-target? → “Resize to [WORD COUNT RANGE] without losing required sections.”
- Union considerations missing? → “Add language acknowledging the CBA and that the CBA governs where different.”

COMMON FOLLOW-UP PROMPTS:
- “Expand Definitions to include [TERM].”
- “Add a procedure step for [SPECIFIC SCENARIO] with timeline and responsible role.”
- “Provide an example for how [STAFF TYPE] uses this policy when [SITUATION].”
- “Revise Scope to exclude contractors and include volunteers.”
- “Break Procedures into a numbered checklist and name any required forms.”
- “Create a simple text flowchart of the approval process.”
- “Rewrite the Employee Acknowledgment in first person (‘I understand…’).”

EXAMPLE VARIABLE SETS:
Example 1: Remote Work Policy
- ORGANIZATION NAME: Coastal Youth Services
- SECTION TOPIC: Remote Work
- MISSION/PROGRAM CONTEXT: We provide mental health counseling and after-school programs to 300 teens annually
- JURISDICTIONS: Washington State
- STAFF TYPES: full-time, part-time (20+ hours), temporary
- WORK MODES: hybrid (counselors on-site 3 days; admin remote)
- UNION STATUS: Non-union
- CAPACITY NOTES: Executive Director handles HR with 4 hours/week; no dedicated HR staff
- READING LEVEL: high school
- TONE: WARM
- LANGUAGE ACCESS: English and Spanish
- IMPLEMENTATION DATE: January 1, 2025
- REVIEW FREQUENCY: annually
- PREPARED BY: Operations Coordinator
- APPROVED BY: Executive Director and Board Personnel Committee
- LEGAL REVIEW: Pro Bono Partnership
- WORD COUNT RANGE: 500–750

Example 2: Harassment and Discrimination Prevention
- ORGANIZATION NAME: Metro Legal Aid
- SECTION TOPIC: Harassment and Discrimination Prevention
- MISSION/PROGRAM CONTEXT: We provide free legal services to low-income residents in housing and family law cases
- JURISDICTIONS: Illinois (including Chicago)
- STAFF TYPES: full-time attorneys, part-time paralegals, law student interns
- WORK MODES: hybrid
- UNION STATUS: Non-union
- CAPACITY NOTES: Operations Manager (0.5 FTE) manages HR; ED involved in investigations
- READING LEVEL: general adult
- TONE: FORMAL
- LANGUAGE ACCESS: English and Spanish
- IMPLEMENTATION DATE: March 1, 2025
- REVIEW FREQUENCY: every two years
- PREPARED BY: Operations Manager
- APPROVED BY: Executive Director and Board
- LEGAL REVIEW: Chicago Volunteer Legal Services (pro bono)
- WORD COUNT RANGE: 800–1,100

---

## 1. Workplace Safety

## 2. Policy Statement

High Desert Community Pantry is dedicated to providing a safe and healthy workplace for all our team members. We require everyone to follow safety rules and report any hazards or injuries promptly. Taking steps to prevent accidents and protect each other is an essential part of our daily work.

## 3. Purpose/Values Link

Ensuring a safe workplace directly supports our mission to deliver healthy food to 1,200 rural households each month. By prioritizing safety, we protect our team, allowing us to consistently and reliably serve our community, especially during warehouse operations and mobile pantry routes.

## 4. Scope/Eligibility

This policy applies to all High Desert Community Pantry team members, including full-time program and warehouse staff, part-time drivers, seasonal helpers, and interns. We are a Non-union workplace. This policy covers all work modes, including on-site warehouse activities and field/mobile distribution efforts. Volunteers and contractors are also expected to follow safety guidelines while engaged in activities for High Desert Community Pantry.

## 5. Definitions

*   **Hazard:** Something that has the potential to cause harm, injury, or illness (e.g., a slippery floor, an unlabeled chemical).
*   **Incident:** An unplanned event that resulted in or could have resulted in injury, illness, or property damage (e.g., a trip, a minor cut, a damaged pallet).
*   **First Aid Injury:** A minor injury that can be treated with basic first aid and does not require professional medical attention (e.g., a small cut, a bruise).
*   **Recordable Injury:** An injury or illness that requires medical treatment beyond first aid, causes lost work time, or restricts normal duties.
*   **Personal Protective Equipment (PPE):** Items worn to minimize exposure to hazards (e.g., gloves, safety vests, steel-toed boots).

## 6. Procedures

Here’s how we handle safety:

1.  **Report a Hazard:**
    *   **Who:** Any team member (full-time, part-time, seasonal, intern, volunteer, contractor).
    *   **What:** Immediately report any unsafe condition or hazard you see. This could be a spill, faulty equipment, or a cluttered aisle.
    *   **When:** As soon as you notice it. If it’s an immediate danger, address it safely if possible (e.g., block off an area), then report it.
    *   **How:** Tell your supervisor or the Operations Coordinator directly. For urgent matters, speak up immediately. Otherwise, send an email or use the "Safety Concern Form" available in the office.
    *   **Example:** An outreach coordinator at a mobile pantry notices a broken step on the ramp to the truck. They should immediately notify the driver and Operations Coordinator.

2.  **Report an Incident or Injury:**
    *   **Who:** The injured team member, or a witness if the injured person cannot report.
    *   **What:** Report all work-related incidents, injuries, or near-misses, no matter how minor.
    *   **When:** Immediately, or as soon as medically safe to do so.
    *   **How:**
        *   **Step 1:** Seek first aid or medical attention if needed right away.
        *   **Step 2:** Inform your supervisor as soon as possible.
        *   **Step 3:** Complete the "Incident Report Form" within 24 hours. The Operations Coordinator can help you fill it out.
    *   **Example:** A program manager lifting a box in the warehouse feels a tweak in their back. They should immediately stop lifting, tell their supervisor, and fill out an Incident Report Form.

3.  **Use of Personal Protective Equipment (PPE):**
    *   **Who:** All team members working in areas requiring PPE.
    *   **What:** Wear required PPE (e.g., safety vests during mobile distributions, gloves for certain tasks in the warehouse). Your supervisor will tell you what’s needed for your role.
    *   **When:** Whenever working in designated areas or performing tasks that require it.
    *   **How:** If you need new or replacement PPE, ask your supervisor or the Operations Coordinator.

4.  **Emergency Procedures:**
    *   **Who:** All team members.
    *   **What:** Familiarize yourself with emergency exits, fire extinguishers, and emergency contact numbers.
    *   **When:** During your onboarding and through periodic refreshers.
    *   **How:** Ask your supervisor or the Operations Coordinator if you have questions about emergency plans.

## 7. Legal/Compliance References

This policy aligns with the New Mexico Occupational Health and Safety Act (NM OHS Act) and related regulations. New Mexico law requires employers to provide a safe workplace free from recognized hazards. All workplace safety practices will adhere to these state and federal requirements. If any local or federal law provides greater protection, that law will supersede this policy.

## 8. Exceptions & Accommodations

We are committed to making our workplace safe and accessible for everyone. If you need any disability accommodations or religious accommodations related to workplace safety (e.g., specific PPE requirements), please discuss your needs with the Operations Director. We aim to respond to all accommodation requests within 5 business days and work with you to find a reasonable solution.

## 9. Reporting/Confidentiality/Anti-retaliation

You can report safety concerns or incidents to your supervisor, the Operations Coordinator, or the Executive Director. We treat all reports with respect and confidentiality, sharing information only as needed to investigate and correct the issue. High Desert Community Pantry has a strict anti-retaliation policy: no one will be penalized or treated unfairly for raising a safety concern or reporting an incident in good faith. Incident and safety records will be maintained for at least five years, or longer as required by New Mexico law.

## 10. Roles & Responsibilities

*   **Employee:** Follow all safety rules, use required PPE, report hazards and incidents promptly, and actively participate in safety training.
*   **Supervisor:** Ensure team members understand and follow safety rules, address hazards promptly, investigate incidents, and ensure PPE is available and used correctly.
*   **Operations Coordinator:** Manages safety records, assists with incident investigations, provides basic safety training, and orders necessary PPE.
*   **Executive Director:** Provides leadership and resources for workplace safety, reviews serious incidents, and ensures compliance with all safety regulations.

## 11. Related Policies

*   Vehicle Use and Accident Reporting
*   Emergency Preparedness Plan
*   Anti-Discrimination and Harassment Policy

## 12. Effective Date/Review

This policy becomes effective on February 1, 2025. It will be reviewed annually to ensure it remains current and effective.

Version 1.0 | Effective February 1, 2025 | Last Reviewed February 1, 2025
This policy does not create an employment contract.

## 13. Employee Acknowledgment

I have received, read, and understand the High Desert Community Pantry Workplace Safety policy. I agree to follow these guidelines to keep myself and my colleagues safe while working. If I have questions, I know who to ask.

---

Prepared by Operations Coordinator | Approved by Executive Director and Board Personnel Committee | Legal review: State Bar of New Mexico Volunteer Attorney Program (pro bono)

**Equity Note:** This policy aims to promote equity by ensuring safety procedures are applied consistently across all roles and work modes, from warehouse staff to mobile distribution teams. It specifically includes provisions for disability and religious accommodations and encourages reporting in English, Spanish, and Navajo to ensure all team members can access critical safety information and report concerns without language barriers, mitigating potential disparate impacts on non-English speakers or those with accessibility needs.

# WORKPLACE SAFETY

**High Desert Community Pantry Employee Handbook**

---

## 1. Title
**Workplace Safety**

---

## 2. Policy Statement
High Desert Community Pantry is committed to providing a safe and healthy workplace for all team members. All employees must follow safety procedures, report hazards and injuries immediately, and use required protective equipment. Supervisors will conduct monthly safety checks of the warehouse and mobile pantry vehicles. We prohibit working under the influence of alcohol or drugs, and we require that all warehouse equipment be operated only by trained staff.

---

## 3. Purpose/Values Link
Safe working conditions allow us to reliably serve the 1,200 rural households who depend on us each month. When our team stays healthy and safe, our community stays fed.

---

## 4. Scope/Eligibility
This policy applies to:
- **Staff types:** Full-time program and warehouse staff, part-time drivers, seasonal helpers, and interns
- **Union status:** Non-union
- **Work modes:** On-site warehouse and field/mobile distribution
- **Volunteers and contractors:** Volunteers must follow all safety procedures; contractors must provide proof of their own safety training and insurance

---

## 5. Definitions
- **Hazard:** Anything that could cause injury, illness, or property damage (spilled liquids, broken pallets, icy steps, malfunctioning lift gates)
- **Injury:** Any harm requiring first aid or medical attention, including cuts, strains, burns, or vehicle accidents
- **Near miss:** An incident that could have caused injury but didn't (a box falls from a shelf but no one is standing nearby)
- **Personal Protective Equipment (PPE):** Safety gear required for specific tasks—steel-toed boots, gloves, reflective vests, back support belts
- **Safety incident:** Any injury, near miss, hazard, or property damage related to work

---

## 6. Procedures

### Reporting a Hazard, Injury, or Near Miss
1. **Employee:** Stop work immediately if unsafe. Tell your supervisor right away—by phone, text, or in person.
2. **Employee:** Complete the **Safety Incident Report Form** within 24 hours and give it to the Operations Coordinator. (Forms are in the warehouse office, on mobile pantry clipboards, and on our shared drive.)
3. **Supervisor:** Respond within 4 hours. If the hazard can be fixed immediately (mop a spill, replace a broken pallet), do it and note the fix on the form. If it requires supplies or outside help, contact the Operations Coordinator.
4. **Operations Coordinator:** Log the incident in the **Safety Incident Log** and take corrective action within 5 business days. Notify the Operations Director of any injury requiring medical care or any pattern of similar incidents.
5. **Operations Director:** Review serious incidents with the Executive Director within 2 business days and determine if additional training, equipment, or policy changes are needed.

### Example Scenario
*Miguel, a part-time driver, notices the lift gate on the mobile pantry van is sticking and making a grinding noise during a delivery to Torreon Chapter House. He texts his supervisor immediately, completes the Safety Incident Report Form when he returns to the warehouse that afternoon, and parks the van with an "Out of Service" note. The Operations Coordinator schedules a repair within three days and assigns Miguel a different vehicle for his next route.*

### Monthly Safety Checks
1. **Supervisors:** Conduct a walkthrough of the warehouse and inspect each mobile pantry vehicle on the first Tuesday of each month using the **Monthly Safety Checklist**.
2. **Supervisors:** Submit the completed checklist to the Operations Coordinator by the first Friday of the month.
3. **Operations Coordinator:** Review all checklists, schedule repairs or replacements, and file checklists in the safety binder (kept for 3 years).

### Personal Protective Equipment (PPE)
1. **Employee:** Wear required PPE for your tasks:
   - Warehouse staff: steel-toed boots, gloves when handling heavy or sharp items
   - Drivers: reflective vest during roadside distributions
   - All staff: closed-toe shoes, no loose jewelry near machinery
2. **Supervisor:** Provide PPE at no cost to employees within 5 business days of hire or task assignment.
3. **Employee:** Report damaged or missing PPE to your supervisor immediately. You will receive a replacement within 2 business days.

---

## 7. Legal/Compliance References
This policy is designed to comply with:
- New Mexico Occupational Health and Safety Act (NMAC 11.5.1)
- New Mexico Workers' Compensation Act (NMSA 1978, §52-1-1 et seq.)
- OSHA General Duty Clause (29 USC §654)

**If state or federal safety regulations are more protective than this policy, those laws apply.** The Operations Coordinator will update this policy as regulations change.

---

## 8. Exceptions & Accommodations
If you need a safety accommodation due to a disability or sincerely held religious belief (e.g., modified PPE, adjusted lifting limits, prayer break during a safety drill), contact the **Operations Director** in writing or by email. We will respond within **5 business days** to discuss options. Accommodations will be provided unless they create an undue hardship or direct threat to safety.

---

## 9. Reporting/Confidentiality/Anti-Retaliation

### Reporting Channels
- Report safety concerns to your supervisor, the Operations Coordinator, the Operations Director, or the Executive Director—whichever you are most comfortable with.
- You may report anonymously by placing a Safety Incident Report Form in the locked suggestion box in the warehouse break room (checked weekly by the Operations Coordinator).

### Confidentiality
We will share safety incident information only with those who need to know (supervisors, Workers' Compensation insurance, medical providers, regulatory agencies). Employee names will be kept confidential to the extent allowed by law.

### Anti-Retaliation
**We prohibit retaliation against anyone who reports a safety concern in good faith.** Retaliation includes demotion, reduced hours, exclusion from meetings, or hostile treatment. If you experience retaliation, report it immediately to the Executive Director or Board Personnel Committee.

### Recordkeeping
- Safety Incident Report Forms and the Safety Incident Log: kept for **3 years**
- Monthly Safety Checklists: kept for **3 years**
- Workers' Compensation claims: kept per New Mexico law (currently 5 years after claim closure)

---

## 10. Roles & Responsibilities

| **Role** | **Responsibilities** |
|----------|---------------------|
| **Employee** | Follow all safety procedures; wear required PPE; report hazards, injuries, and near misses within 24 hours; ask questions if unsure |
| **Supervisor** | Conduct monthly safety checks; respond to hazard reports within 4 hours; provide PPE; model safe practices; never pressure staff to work unsafely |
| **Operations Coordinator** | Maintain Safety Incident Log and safety binder; coordinate repairs and PPE orders; schedule annual safety training |
| **Operations Director** | Review serious incidents; approve accommodation requests; ensure compliance with New Mexico safety laws |
| **Executive Director** | Allocate budget for safety equipment and training; review policy annually; communicate safety priorities to the Board |

---

## 11. Related Policies
- **Vehicle Use and Accident Reporting** (procedures for mobile pantry vehicle incidents)
- **Workers' Compensation and Return to Work** (benefits and modified duty after injury)
- **Emergency Procedures and Evacuation** (fire, severe weather, active threat)
- **Volunteer Safety and Supervision** (safety expectations for non-employee volunteers)

---

## 12. Effective Date/Review
- **Effective:** February 1, 2025  
- **Review:** Annually (next review February 2026)  
- **Version:** Version 1.0 | Effective February 1, 2025 | Last Reviewed January 20, 2025  

**Disclaimer:** This policy does not create an employment contract. High Desert Community Pantry reserves the right to modify this policy at any time with notice to employees.

---

## 13. Employee Acknowledgment
I have received, read, and understand the Workplace Safety policy. I agree to follow all safety procedures, use required protective equipment, and report hazards and injuries promptly. I know I can ask my supervisor or the Operations Coordinator if I have questions or need help staying safe at work.

**Employee Signature:** ______________________________

### Authorship
**Prepared by:** Operations Coordinator

### Equity Note

- **Language barriers:** This policy is available in English, Spanish, and Navajo. Safety trainings and PPE instructions will be provided in all three languages. Pictorial guides will supplement written instructions.
- **Physical limitations:** Employees with disabilities may request accommodations (e.g., mechanical lifting aids, modified PPE) without penalty. Seasonal and part-time staff receive the same PPE and safety protections as full-time staff.
- **Field vs. warehouse:** Mobile distribution sites present unique hazards (weather, uneven terrain, traffic). Drivers receive route-specific safety briefings and have authority to postpone distribution if conditions are unsafe.

1. Title
Workplace Safety Policy

2. Policy Statement
- We require safe work practices in our warehouse and at all mobile pantry sites. Use required PPE (closed‑toe shoes, work gloves, and high‑visibility vests on routes), follow lifting rules, wear seat belts, and do not use phones while driving. Report hazards, near misses, and injuries within 24 hours using our forms. Only trained staff may use pallet jacks, lift gates, or other equipment. We may pause or relocate work for heat, lightning, smoke, or icy conditions.

3. Purpose/Values Link
Safety helps us deliver healthy food to 1,200 rural households each month without harm to staff, volunteers, or neighbors. Protecting each other keeps our mission moving.

4. Scope/Eligibility
- Staff types: full-time program and warehouse staff, part-time drivers, seasonal helpers, interns
- Union status: Non-union
- Work modes: on-site warehouse and field/mobile distribution
- Volunteers: included when serving with us
- Contractors: not covered by this policy, but must follow our site rules under their contract

Note: Policy and forms are available in English, Spanish, and Navajo. Ask your supervisor if you need an interpreter or translation.

5. Definitions
- Hazard: Anything that can cause harm (e.g., unstable pallet, slick ramp, extreme heat).
- Near Miss: A safety event with no injury but could have caused one.
- Incident: An injury, illness, property damage, vehicle crash, or exposure.
- PPE: Personal protective equipment (gloves, vests, closed‑toe shoes, masks if needed).
- Stop‑Work Authority: Anyone can pause unsafe work until it is fixed.

6. Procedures
1) If it’s unsafe, stop.
- Who: Any employee or volunteer
- What: Pause the task; move to a safe area
- When: Immediately
- Form/Tool: None; notify Supervisor on site

2) Medical needs
- Who: Supervisor
- What: Call 911 for life‑threats; use first aid kit; arrange urgent care when needed
- When: Immediately
- Form/Tool: First Aid Kit Log (in vehicles and warehouse)

3) Report incidents and near misses
- Who: Employee or witness; Supervisor helps if needed
- What: Complete Incident Report Form
- When: Within 24 hours (same shift if possible)
- Form/Tool: Incident Report Form; submit to Operations Coordinator

- Who: Drivers
- What: Pre‑trip Daily Vehicle Checklist; seat belts on; no handheld phones; follow speed limits
- When: Before each trip; during all driving
- Form/Tool: Daily Vehicle Checklist
- If crash: secure scene, call 911 if needed, inform Supervisor, complete Accident Report within 24 hours

5) Lifting and equipment
- Who: All staff and volunteers
- What: Use two‑person lift or pallet jack for loads over 50 lbs; only trained staff use lift gates/pallet jacks
- When: Every shift
- Form/Tool: Posted Lift Guide; Equipment Training Log

- Who: Anyone can report; Supervisor mitigates; Operations Coordinator tracks
- What: Submit Safety Concern Card or Online Safety Log; Supervisor addresses quick fixes; complex issues go to Operations Coordinator
- When: Report same shift; triage within 2 business days; fix as soon as practical

7) Site checks
- Who: Warehouse Lead or designee
- What: Weekly Warehouse Safety Checklist; monthly vehicle inspection review
- When: Weekly/monthly
- Form/Tool: Warehouse Safety Checklist; Vehicle Inspection Log

8) Weather and heat
- Who: Route Lead or Supervisor
- What: Use Heat/Weather Pause Protocol (water every hour, shade/rest breaks, reschedule during lightning/icy lots/wildfire smoke)
- When: As conditions require
- Form/Tool: Heat/Weather Pause Protocol

9) Workers’ compensation and return to work
- Who: Operations Coordinator starts claim; Executive Director confirms work status
- What: File workers’ comp claim; follow doctor’s restrictions
- When: Within 24 hours of notice of injury
- Form/Tool: Workers’ Compensation Claim Packet; Return‑to‑Work Note

Examples:
- Mobile pantry in Tohajiilee: Route Lead pauses unloading when lightning starts, moves crew into vehicles, and reschedules the stop.
- Warehouse: A helper trips on plastic wrap, is checked by first aid, and files the Incident Report Form before leaving.

7. Legal/Compliance References
- New Mexico Occupational Health and Safety Act (NMSA 1978, §50‑9‑1 et seq.) and OHSB rules (11.5 NMAC); OSHA severe injury reporting: fatality within 8 hours; inpatient hospitalization, amputation, or loss of an eye within 24 hours to NM OHSB.
- New Mexico Workers’ Compensation Act (NMSA 1978, §52‑1).
- New Mexico seat belt law (NMSA 1978, §66‑7‑372).
- New Mexico Dee Johnson Clean Indoor Air Act (NMSA 1978, §24‑16).
If this policy conflicts with law, New Mexico law governs.

- Contact: Operations Director
- How: Email or form (Accommodation Request Form); you may ask for help completing it
- When: We respond within 5 business days and begin an interactive process
We may request medical or faith documentation if needed.

9. Reporting/Confidentiality/Anti‑retaliation
Report to your Supervisor or directly to the Operations Coordinator; you may also contact the Executive Director. We protect privacy and keep medical information confidential, sharing only with those who need to know. No retaliation for raising safety concerns or using stop‑work authority. Records (incidents, training, inspections) are kept at least 5 years or per law.

### 1. Policy Statement

All employees of Harbor City Public Health Education Alliance are required to accurately record their work hours and breaks in accordance with federal, New York, and New Jersey state laws. Non-exempt employees are eligible for overtime compensation for hours worked in excess of 40 in a workweek, consistent with legal requirements. This policy outlines the procedures for timekeeping and overtime authorization, ensuring fair and accurate payroll processing.

### 2. Purpose/Values Link

Accurate timekeeping and proper overtime management are fundamental to our operational integrity and ensure we can sustain our mission of providing evidence-based health education workshops that strengthen communities. By adhering to these guidelines, we maintain transparent and efficient practices that support our staff, allowing us to effectively deliver vital health information.

### 3. Scope/Eligibility

This policy applies to all full-time exempt managers, full-time and part-time non-exempt health educators, AmeriCorps members, and interns. Harbor City Public Health Education Alliance is a non-union organization. Staff members operate in a hybrid work environment, which includes dedicated office days (typically two days per week), field workshops, and limited remote administrative tasks. Volunteers and contractors are excluded from this timekeeping and overtime policy.

### 4. Definitions

*   **Workweek:** A fixed and regularly recurring period of 168 hours, or seven consecutive 24-hour periods, starting at 12:01 AM on Monday and ending at 12:00 AM on the following Monday.
*   **Non-Exempt Employee:** An employee who is eligible for overtime pay under federal and state wage and hour laws, typically paid hourly.
*   **Exempt Employee:** An employee who is not eligible for overtime pay under federal and state wage and hour laws, typically paid a salary and meeting specific duties tests.
*   **Compensable Time:** All time an employee is engaged in employers-assigned duties, including but not limited to direct work, training, and required travel.
*   **Overtime:** Hours worked by a non-exempt employee in excess of 40 in a single workweek, for which compensation at a rate of one and one-half times the regular rate of pay is required.

### 5. Procedures

All timekeeping and overtime procedures are managed through Gusto, our designated payroll and HR platform.

1.  **Non-Exempt Employee Time Recording:**
    *   **WHO:** Full-time and part-time non-exempt health educators, AmeriCorps members, and interns.
    *   **WHAT:** Record all hours worked, including start times, end times, and unpaid meal breaks (typically 30-60 minutes, if applicable), accurately in Gusto. This applies whether conducting a workshop at a public library or performing limited remote administrative work.
    *   **WHEN:** Daily, before the end of the workday. Final approval and submission must occur no later than the end of the business day on Friday of each week.
2.  **Overtime Authorization for Non-Exempt Employees:**
    *   **WHO:** Non-exempt employees seeking to work overtime and their Supervisors.
    *   **WHAT:** Non-exempt employees must obtain explicit written authorization from their direct supervisor *before* working any hours that would result in overtime (exceeding 40 hours in a workweek). For instance, an outreach coordinator assisting with a late-evening community event and anticipating exceeding 40 hours for the week must secure this approval in advance.
    *   **WHEN:** Prior to performing any work that would cause weekly hours to exceed 40.
3.  **Supervisor Review and Approval:**
    *   **WHO:** Supervisors of non-exempt employees.
    *   **WHAT:** Review and approve direct reports' timesheets in Gusto, verifying accuracy and confirming any authorized overtime.
    *   **WHEN:** By Monday of the following week, ensuring payroll processing deadlines are met.
4.  **Exempt Employee Time Recording:**
    *   **WHO:** Full-time exempt managers.
    *   **WHAT:** Record any approved time off (e.g., vacation, sick leave) in Gusto. Daily work hours are not tracked for payroll purposes as they are salaried employees.
    *   **WHEN:** As occurrences arise and as per the Paid Time Off policy.
5.  **Operations Manager Payroll Processing:**
    *   **WHO:** Operations Manager.
    *   **WHAT:** Verify all timesheets are approved, address any discrepancies, and process payroll using Gusto.
    *   **WHEN:** Bi-weekly, according to the established payroll schedule.

### 6. Legal/Compliance References

This policy adheres to the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA), the New York Labor Law, particularly regarding minimum wage, overtime, and meal/rest breaks, and the New Jersey Wage and Hour Law. Where New York or New Jersey law provides greater protections or is more stringent than federal law, or where local ordinances supersede state law, the more favorable provision for the employee will govern. Employees are encouraged to familiarize themselves with these laws as they pertain to their employment and compensation.

### 7. Exceptions & Accommodations

Harbor City Public Health Education Alliance is committed to providing reasonable accommodations for employees with disabilities or sincerely held religious beliefs, in accordance with applicable federal and state laws. To request an accommodation related to timekeeping procedures or any aspect of this policy, employees should contact the Operations Manager. Requests will be reviewed within 5 business days, and a determination will be communicated promptly.

### 8. Reporting/Confidentiality/Anti-retaliation

Employees who believe there has been an error in their timekeeping or overtime calculation, or who have concerns about this policy, should first discuss the matter with their immediate supervisor. If the issue cannot be resolved, or if the employee prefers, they may report their concerns directly to the Operations Manager. All reports will be handled with appropriate discretion and confidentiality to the extent possible, consistent with a thorough investigation. Harbor City Public Health Education Alliance prohibits any form of retaliation against employees who, in good faith, report concerns or participate in an investigation. All timekeeping records and related documentation will be maintained for the period required by federal and state laws, or longer if deemed necessary for organizational purposes.

### 9. Roles & Responsibilities

*   **Employee (Non-Exempt):** Accurately record all hours worked and breaks in Gusto; obtain pre-approval for any anticipated overtime.
*   **Employee (Exempt):** Accurately record approved time off in Gusto.
*   **Supervisor:** Review and approve direct reports' timesheets in Gusto weekly; authorize all overtime for non-exempt staff in advance.
*   **Operations Manager:** Oversee and manage the timekeeping and payroll system (Gusto); address discrepancies; process payroll; manage HR-related inquiries; handle accommodation requests.
*   **Executive Director:** Provide strategic oversight for all organizational policies and ensure compliance.

### 10. Related Policies

*   Paid Time Off Policy
*   Employee Conduct Policy
*   Workplace Safety Policy
*   Remote Work Policy

### 11. Effective Date/Review

Version 1.0 | Effective April 1, 2025 | Last Reviewed March 1, 2025

This policy will be reviewed every two years to ensure continued relevance and compliance with all applicable laws. This policy does not create an employment contract.

### 12. Employee Acknowledgment

I acknowledge that I have received, read, and understand the Timekeeping and Overtime policy of Harbor City Public Health Education Alliance. I agree to adhere to the procedures outlined herein, including submitting accurate timesheets and obtaining prior authorization for any overtime hours.

# EMPLOYEE HANDBOOK SECTION: TIMEKEEPING AND OVERTIME

---

## 1. Title
**Timekeeping and Overtime**

---

## 2. Policy Statement
All employees must accurately record all hours worked using the Gusto timekeeping system. Non-exempt employees must obtain supervisor approval before working overtime. Falsification of time records or unauthorized overtime may result in disciplinary action, up to and including termination. Employees will be paid in accordance with federal and state wage and hour laws.

---

## 3. Purpose/Values Link
Accurate timekeeping ensures that Harbor City Public Health Education Alliance can fulfill its mission to provide evidence-based health education workshops in schools, libraries, and community centers across two states by maintaining fiscal accountability and treating all staff equitably. This policy protects both the organization and employees by ensuring compliance with wage and hour laws.

---

## 4. Scope/Eligibility

**This policy applies to:**
- **Non-exempt employees:** Full-time and part-time health educators (eligible for overtime pay)
- **Exempt employees:** Full-time managers (not eligible for overtime pay)
- **AmeriCorps members:** Subject to AmeriCorps-specific timekeeping requirements and not eligible for overtime
- **Interns:** Must track hours; unpaid interns are not eligible for overtime

**Work modes:** Applies to all work performed in office settings (2 days/week), during field workshops at schools/libraries/community centers, and limited remote administrative work.

**Union status:** Non-union.

**Volunteers and independent contractors** are excluded from this policy and follow separate timekeeping procedures.

---

## 5. Definitions

- **Hours Worked:** All time an employee is required or permitted to work, including time spent in training, staff meetings, travel between workshop sites during the workday, and work performed at home with supervisor authorization.
- **Overtime:** Hours worked beyond 40 hours in a workweek (New York and New Jersey standard). Calculated weekly, Sunday through Saturday.
- **Non-Exempt Employee:** An employee entitled to minimum wage and overtime pay under the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) and state law; includes all health educators.
- **Exempt Employee:** An employee not entitled to overtime pay due to job duties and salary level meeting FLSA and state exemption tests; includes managers.
- **Workweek:** Sunday 12:00 a.m. through Saturday 11:59 p.m.

---

## 6. Procedures

### Timekeeping Procedures for Non-Exempt Employees

1. **Employee logs in to Gusto** at the start of each work period and logs out at the end, recording actual time worked (not scheduled time). This applies to office days, field workshops, and authorized remote work.
   
2. **Employee records meal breaks** of 30 minutes or more when no work is performed. Meal breaks are unpaid.

3. **Employee submits timesheet** in Gusto by 9:00 a.m. Monday for the prior workweek (Sunday–Saturday).

4. **Supervisor reviews and approves timesheet** in Gusto within two business days of submission, confirming accuracy.

5. **Operations Manager processes payroll** based on approved timesheets; payroll runs biweekly.

### Overtime Authorization Procedures

6. **Employee anticipating overtime** (e.g., health educator scheduled for evening workshop that will exceed 40 hours that week) must submit a written request via email to their supervisor at least 48 hours in advance, unless emergency circumstances prevent advance notice.

7. **Supervisor approves or denies request** via email within 24 hours. Approval must be obtained before overtime is worked except in emergencies.

8. **Employee works authorized overtime** and records all hours in Gusto.

9. **Operations Manager reviews overtime hours** during payroll processing to ensure proper authorization and payment at 1.5 times the regular rate.

**Example:** A part-time health educator scheduled for workshops Monday–Thursday (32 hours) is asked to cover a Friday evening library session (6 hours). The educator emails their supervisor on Wednesday requesting overtime authorization. The supervisor approves, and the educator records 38 total hours, with no overtime owed (under 40 hours). If the same educator also works a Saturday community event (4 hours), bringing the total to 42 hours, the educator earns 2 hours of overtime pay at 1.5 times their regular rate.

---

## 7. Legal/Compliance References

This policy is designed to comply with:
- Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA), 29 U.S.C. § 201 et seq.
- **New York:** New York Labor Law §§ 190–199, 12 NYCRR Part 142 (wage orders); New York minimum wage and overtime standards
- **New Jersey:** New Jersey Wage and Hour Law, N.J.S.A. 34:11-56a et seq.; New Jersey minimum wage and overtime standards

Where state or local law provides greater protections or benefits than this policy, the law supersedes this policy. Employees working in multiple jurisdictions will be subject to the law of the state where the work is performed.

---

## 8. Exceptions & Accommodations

Employees requiring modifications to timekeeping or scheduling procedures due to disability or sincerely held religious beliefs must submit a written accommodation request to the Operations Manager. The Operations Manager will respond within five business days to initiate the interactive accommodation process. All requests will be evaluated individually; accommodations will be provided unless they create an undue hardship for the organization.

**Contact:** Operations Manager | operations@harborcitypublichealth.org

---

## 9. Reporting/Confidentiality/Anti-Retaliation

**Reporting Timekeeping Violations:**
Employees who believe their time has been inaccurately recorded, that they have not been paid for all hours worked, or that they have been pressured to work off the clock must report concerns immediately to:
1. Direct supervisor (if the supervisor is not involved in the concern), or
2. Operations Manager, or
3. Executive Director

**Confidentiality:** Reports will be handled discreetly. Information will be shared only with individuals who need to know to investigate and resolve the issue.

**Anti-Retaliation:** Harbor City Public Health Education Alliance prohibits retaliation against any employee who reports timekeeping concerns in good faith or participates in an investigation. Retaliation is grounds for disciplinary action up to and including termination.

**Recordkeeping:** Time records will be maintained for a minimum of six years in accordance with New York and New Jersey recordkeeping requirements.

---

## 10. Roles & Responsibilities

**Employee:**
- Accurately record all hours worked in Gusto
- Submit timesheets by the Monday 9:00 a.m. deadline
- Request overtime authorization in advance when possible
- Report timekeeping errors or concerns immediately

**Supervisor:**
- Review and approve timesheets within two business days
- Approve or deny overtime requests within 24 hours
- Monitor workloads to minimize unplanned overtime
- Ensure employees do not work off the clock

**Operations Manager:**
- Maintain and administer the Gusto timekeeping system
- Process payroll based on approved timesheets
- Monitor overtime trends and report to Executive Director
- Respond to accommodation requests within five business days
- Investigate timekeeping complaints

**Executive Director:**
- Review overtime trends and approve budgetary adjustments as needed
- Serve as escalation point for unresolved timekeeping disputes
- Ensure organizational compliance with wage and hour laws

---

## 11. Related Policies

- Compensation and Pay Practices
- Paid Time Off
- Travel and Expense Reimbursement
- Remote Work

---

## 12. Effective Date/Review

**Effective Date:** April 1, 2025  
**Review Frequency:** Every two years  
**Version Control:** Version 1.0 | Effective April 1, 2025 | Last Reviewed March 2025

**Disclaimer:** This policy does not create an employment contract, express or implied. Harbor City Public Health Education Alliance retains the right to modify this policy at any time with or without notice. Employment remains at-will.

    *   **WHO:** HR Director, in consultation with the Executive Director and legal counsel.

---

### 1. Title
**Workplace Violence Prevention**

---

### 2. Policy Statement
Pacific Coast Conservation Trust prohibits all forms of workplace violence, including threats, intimidation, physical assault, and behavior that creates a reasonable fear of harm. All employees must report any incident, threat, or concern regarding workplace violence immediately to their supervisor or the HR Director. Violations of this policy will result in disciplinary action up to and including termination, and may involve law enforcement notification. The Trust will investigate all reports promptly and take appropriate corrective action.

---

### 3. Purpose/Values Link
Our staff, volunteers, and visitors depend on safe preserves, trails, and visitor centers to carry out our mission of coastal habitat protection and environmental education. A violence-free workplace ensures that our team of 100,000 annual visitor interactions and sensitive conservation work can proceed without fear or disruption.

---

### 4. Scope/Eligibility
This policy applies to:

- **Staff types:** Full-time administrative and program staff, part-time visitor center associates, seasonal field technicians, and interns.
- **Union status:** SEIU Local 1021 members are covered by this policy; where the collective bargaining agreement (CBA) contains different or additional provisions on workplace safety or discipline, the CBA governs.
- **Work modes:** Hybrid administrative staff, on-site preserve and visitor center staff, and field-based conservation crews.
- **Volunteers and contractors:** Volunteers working at preserves and visitor centers are covered. Independent contractors and vendors must comply while on Trust property or at Trust-sponsored events; the Trust may terminate contracts for violations.

---

### 5. Definitions

- **Workplace violence:** Any physical assault, threatening behavior, intimidation, harassment, or other conduct that creates a reasonable fear of injury to oneself or others. Includes acts occurring on Trust property, at off-site Trust events, in Trust vehicles, or directed at Trust employees during work-related activities.

- **Threat:** Any verbal, written, electronic, or physical expression of intent to cause harm, damage property, or interfere with operations. Includes direct statements, implied warnings, and gestures that a reasonable person would perceive as menacing.

- **Credible threat of violence:** A knowing and willful statement or course of conduct that would cause a reasonable person to fear for their safety or the safety of others, and that serves no legitimate purpose. May include stalking, repeated unwanted contact, or display of weapons.

- **Immediate danger:** A situation in which an individual reasonably believes that violence is imminent or in progress, requiring urgent protective action or law enforcement response.

- **Incident log:** The confidential record maintained by the HR Director documenting all reported workplace violence concerns, investigations, and outcomes, retained per California recordkeeping requirements.

---

### 6. Procedures

#### A. Reporting a Workplace Violence Incident or Concern

1. **Employee (or volunteer):** If you witness or experience workplace violence or a credible threat, remove yourself from immediate danger if safe to do so. Call 911 if there is immediate danger or a crime in progress.

2. **Employee:** Report the incident or threat to your direct supervisor and the HR Director within **24 hours** of the incident or as soon as it is safe to do so. Use the **Workplace Violence Incident Report Form** (available on the staff intranet, at visitor centers, and from the HR Generalist). Provide date, time, location, individuals involved, witnesses, and a description of the behavior.

3. **Supervisor:** Upon receiving a report, immediately notify the HR Director. If the HR Director is the subject of the report, notify the Executive Director. Ensure the reporting employee is safe and separated from the alleged aggressor if necessary.

4. **HR Director:** Acknowledge receipt of the report within **one business day**. Log the incident in the confidential incident log. Assess whether immediate safety measures (e.g., schedule change, restricted access, temporary leave) are needed and implement within **two business days**.

#### B. Investigation

5. **HR Director:** Initiate investigation within **three business days** of receiving the report. If the alleged conduct involves serious threats, weapons, or physical violence, consult the Executive Director and outside counsel (Smith & Chen LLP) before proceeding.

6. **HR Director (with HR Generalist support):** Interview the complainant, alleged aggressor, and witnesses. Collect written statements, emails, texts, or other documentation. Maintain confidentiality to the extent possible; share information only on a need-to-know basis.

7. **HR Director:** Complete the investigation and prepare a written summary of findings within **15 business days** of the initial report. For complex cases involving remote preserves or multiple witnesses, extend the timeline by up to **10 business days** and notify the complainant and Executive Director of the delay.

8. **HR Director:** Submit findings and recommended corrective action to the Executive Director. Recommendations may include coaching, formal warning, suspension, termination, restraining order assistance, or law enforcement referral.

#### C. Resolution and Follow-Up

9. **Executive Director:** Review findings and approve corrective action within **five business days**. For termination or legal referrals, consult Smith & Chen LLP before finalizing.

10. **HR Director:** Notify the complainant and the subject of the investigation of the outcome in writing within **three business days** of Executive Director approval. Disclosures will respect privacy and comply with California law; the complainant will be informed that corrective action was taken (or not), but personnel details may be limited.

11. **HR Director:** Implement corrective action immediately upon approval. Update the incident log. Schedule a follow-up conversation with the complainant within **30 days** to assess safety and any retaliation concerns.

12. **HR Director:** If the incident involved a remote preserve or field crew, coordinate with the relevant Program Manager to brief staff on general safety reminders (without disclosing confidential details) within **two weeks** of resolution.

#### D. Training and Prevention

13. **HR Director and HR Generalist:** Provide annual workplace violence prevention training to all staff. For on-site and field staff, deliver in-person or live virtual sessions; for remote or geographically dispersed teams, offer recorded modules with acknowledgment due within **30 days** of hire or annually by **September 30**. Training will be available in English, Spanish, and Mandarin.

14. **All employees:** Complete assigned training by the due date. Sign and return the **Workplace Violence Training Acknowledgment Form** to the HR Generalist.

**Example:** A visitor center associate working a crowded free-admission weekend notices a visitor loudly berating a colleague and gesturing aggressively near the gift shop. The associate alerts the on-site supervisor, who escorts the visitor outside and calls the HR Director within one hour. The HR Director logs the incident, interviews the staff member and supervisor the next business day, and coordinates with the Executive Director to issue a trespass notice to the visitor.

---

### 7. Legal/Compliance References
This policy is designed to comply with:

- California Labor Code § 6401.7 (workplace violence prevention requirements for employers)
- California Code of Regulations, Title 8, § 3342 (Cal/OSHA workplace violence prevention in general industry)
- California Penal Code § 422 (criminal threats)
- California Civil Code § 527.8 (workplace violence restraining orders)

Where state, county, or local ordinances impose greater protections or reporting obligations, those laws supersede this policy. SEIU Local 1021 members should refer to the collective bargaining agreement for any additional safety grievance procedures or investigatory rights; the CBA controls where it conflicts with this handbook.

---

### 8. Exceptions & Accommodations
Employees who require disability-related or religious accommodations in connection with this policy (e.g., alternative reporting methods, modified training formats, safety planning for disability-related vulnerabilities) should contact the **HR Director** in writing or via email. The HR Director will engage in an interactive process and respond with next steps within **five business days**. Accommodations will be provided unless they impose an undue hardship on the Trust or compromise safety.

---

### 9. Reporting/Confidentiality/Anti-Retaliation

**Reporting Channels:**
- Direct supervisor
- HR Director: [hr@pacificcoastconservation.org] or [phone number]
- Executive Director (if the HR Director is the subject of the concern)
- Anonymous hotline: [phone number or third-party service, if available]

**Confidentiality:** The Trust will maintain confidentiality to the extent possible. Information will be shared only with individuals who have a legitimate need to know in order to investigate, remedy, or prevent violence. Some disclosures may be required by law or necessary to protect health and safety.

**Anti-Retaliation:** Retaliation against any individual who reports workplace violence, participates in an investigation, or supports a complainant is strictly prohibited and will result in disciplinary action up to and including termination. Employees who believe they have experienced retaliation should report immediately to the HR Director or Executive Director.

**Recordkeeping:** The HR Director will retain all Workplace Violence Incident Report Forms, investigation notes, and corrective action records for a minimum of **five years** from the date of resolution, or longer if required by California law or ongoing legal proceedings. Records are stored securely and accessible only to the HR Director, HR Generalist, Executive Director, and outside counsel.

---

### 10. Roles & Responsibilities

**Employee:**
- Comply with this policy and refrain from any act of workplace violence.
- Report incidents, threats, or safety concerns immediately.
- Participate cooperatively in investigations.
- Complete required training by assigned deadlines.

**Supervisor:**
- Receive and escalate reports to the HR Director within 24 hours.

- Ensure compliance with California law and the CBA.

**Executive Director:**
- Review investigation findings and approve disciplinary or corrective action.
- Consult with outside counsel on complex or high-risk matters.

- Report summary data on workplace violence incidents to the Board Safety Committee annually.

**Board Safety Committee:**
- Review aggregate incident data and policy effectiveness annually.

---

### 11. Related Policies

- Incident Reporting and Investigation
- Discipline and Termination

### 12. Effective Date/Review

- **Effective Date:** July 1, 2025

- Violent Incident Log: HR’s secure record of reported incidents and near-misses, used for hazard analysis and required by California law.

6. Procedures
1) Immediate danger (life safety first)
   - Who/What: Any employee experiencing or witnessing violence or a credible threat calls 911 immediately and moves to a safe location. If at a preserve or visitor center, alert a colleague and follow the site’s emergency plan.
   - When: Immediately.
   - Tools: Site Emergency Action Plan; emergency numbers posted at each site.
   - Next: Notify your Supervisor and HR Director or HR Generalist as soon as it is safe.

2) Non-immediate threats or concerning behavior
   - Who/What: Employee completes the WVPP Incident Report Form and alerts Supervisor or HR.
   - When: Within 24 hours of the incident or discovery.
   - Tools: WVPP Incident Report Form (HR SharePoint); option to email safety@pcctrust.org or call HR.
   - Content: Include date/time/location, people involved, description, any injuries, and any video/photos/witnesses.

3) Initial risk assessment and interim safety measures
   - Who/What: HR Director (or HR Generalist if HR Director unavailable) and Supervisor review the report, classify risk, and implement interim controls (e.g., schedule changes, escorts, buddy system, closing an area, trespass notice, removing a threatening visitor, remote work for affected staff).
   - When: Same business day if received by 2 p.m.; otherwise by next business day.
   - Tools: Interim Safety Measures Checklist; Trespass/Exclusion Notice template; coordination with local law enforcement as needed.

4) Investigation
   - Who/What: HR Director leads the investigation; HR Generalist assists. They collect statements, review footage or messages, consult with the Supervisor, and offer represented employees the right to union representation.
   - When: Start within 2 business days; aim to conclude within 10 business days when practical.
   - Tools: Interview Notes Template; Evidence Log; access to Smith & Chen LLP for restraining order or complex issues.

5) Documentation and logging
   - Who/What: HR Generalist enters the event into the Violent Incident Log and files all forms securely.
   - When: Within 2 business days of receipt of the Incident Report.
   - Tools: Violent Incident Log (secure HR drive); file naming protocol.

6) Corrective and protective actions
   - Who/What: HR Director and Supervisor implement findings (e.g., coaching, training, discipline up to termination, changes to site layout, additional signage, temporary closure, safety escorts, workplace violence restraining order under CCP §527.8).
   - When: Within 5 business days of investigation close, or sooner if safety requires.
   - Tools: Corrective Action Plan; Facilities/Security Work Order; Legal counsel referral.

7) Communication and follow-up
   - Who/What: HR informs affected employees about protective steps and, when permitted, the outcome. HR schedules a check-in and updates the plan if needed.
   - When: Within 2 business days of action taken; follow-up within 10 business days.
   - Tools: Employee Notification Template; WVPP Plan Update Log.

8) Training and drills
   - Who/What: HR provides onboarding WVPP training (English, Spanish, Mandarin) and annual refresher. Due to remote sites, training is delivered as a 45–60 minute virtual module plus brief “tailgate” safety talks during scheduled field visits.
   - When: Onboarding within 30 days of hire; annually by June 30; tailgate talks quarterly.
   - Tools: LMS module link; Tailgate Talk Sheet; Training Attendance Roster.

9) Employee participation and hazard reporting
   - Who/What: Employees and SEIU stewards may suggest improvements via the Safety Suggestion Form or during tailgate talks.
   - When: Anytime; HR reviews suggestions monthly.
   - Tools: Safety Suggestion Form (online or paper).

Field scenarios
- Visitor center associate during a free-admission weekend: A visitor shouts and pounds the counter. Staff step back, use de-escalation phrases, press the discreet alert, and the Supervisor escorts the visitor out. An Incident Report is filed the same day.
- Seasonal field technician at a trail easement: An angry landowner blocks access and makes a threat. Crew relocates to vehicles, calls 911, notifies Supervisor and HR, and completes the Incident Report. HR considers a trespass notice and law enforcement liaison before future visits.

7. Legal/Compliance References
- California Labor Code §6401.9 (Workplace Violence Prevention in General Industry).
- Cal/OSHA Injury and Illness Prevention Program: Title 8 CCR §3203.
- California Code of Civil Procedure §527.8 (Workplace Violence Restraining Orders).
- Applicable local ordinances or park district rules. Where local law is more protective, the local law controls.

8. Exceptions & Accommodations
Employees needing disability- or religion-related adjustments to training, response measures, or workplace changes may request an accommodation from the HR Director. HR will acknowledge within 2 business days and issue a written decision within 5 business days after receiving necessary documentation, unless additional time is required by law or to obtain medical information.

9. Reporting/Confidentiality/Anti‑retaliation
- Reporting channels: Supervisor; HR Director; HR Generalist; safety@pcctrust.org; 911 for emergencies.
- Confidentiality: Information is shared only with those who need to know to assess risk, comply with law, or implement safety measures. Absolute confidentiality cannot be guaranteed.
- Anti-retaliation: Retaliation against any person who reports, participates in an investigation, requests a safety measure, or seeks an accommodation is prohibited.
- Recordkeeping: WVPP, training records, Incident Reports, and the Violent Incident Log are maintained by HR for at least five years or longer if required by law or grant terms.

10. Roles & Responsibilities
- Employee: Follow this policy; report incidents within 24 hours; complete training; use de-escalation and safety measures; cooperate in investigations.
- Supervisor: Ensure safe practices; respond to reports the same day; coordinate interim measures; support HR in investigations; schedule staff for required training.
- Operations/HR (HR Director, HR Generalist): Maintain WVPP and log; deliver training; investigate; coordinate legal/law enforcement; track corrective actions; ensure language access in English, Spanish, and Mandarin.
- Executive Director: Approve major corrective actions and site closures; allocate resources; sign restraining order requests as needed.
- Board Safety Committee: Review annual WVPP effectiveness, incident trends, and resource needs; approve policy updates.
